newsitem.title: UK: Boeing and Airbus in air show sales bonanza.
newsitem.headline: Boeing and Airbus in air show sales bonanza.

text.p: Arch rivals Boeing and Airbus gave the aviation industry a major post-recession boost on Wednesday, announcing billion dollar orders at Britain's biggest airshow.
World leader Boeing added to bulging order books with a $1.18 billion deal to sell seven 747-400 jumbo jets to Philippine Airlines.
Not to be outdone in their fierce sales war, the European Airbus Industrie group said it expected another $5 billion of orders to be confirmed soon.
Total sales announced at the aviation showcase by the two top manufacturers alone have now topped $10 billion after just three days of spirited dealings.
This is in sharp contrast to the $3 billion total for the whole industry at the last Farnborough show in 1994.
Boeing and Airbus bickered over market share and argued over the value of producing a new "superjumbo". But both agreed that business was brisk.
"Traffic is up and airline profits are up," said Boeing Commercial Airplane Group President Ron Woodard.
Airbus's chief operating officer, Volker von Tein, echoed his optimism, saying: "A number of airlines, after many years of deficit, are trading at a profit."
But with development costs soaring and competition stiff, the message from civil aviation and defence industry chiefs was the same -- mergers are vital to survival.
"The projects of tomorrow are going to be very, very expensive," Britain's deputy prime minister, Michael Heseltine, warned when opening the show on Monday.
U.S manufacturers have bitten the bullet with a series of mega-mergers. Europe will have to follow suit to compete, industry chiefs say.

Britain gave the production go-ahead for 232 Eurofighter combat jets, a major boost for its joint venture with Germany, Italy and Spain that has been dogged by years of political wrangling and cost overruns.
With 70,000 jobs across the continent depending on the Eurofighter, trade unions urged Britain's three partners to sign up.
"We are confident the British decision will put pressure on our government to make its own decision," said German trade union spokeswoman Ingrid Lullmann.
In a joint statement, the unions also urged France and Germany not to abandon European industry plans to develop a rival to Lockheed's Hercules military transporter.
The members of the four-nation Airbus Industrie consortium are pressing ahead with plans to merge their civil aircraft production plants into one company.
But there are also aspirations within the group to take over and consolidate Europe's defence industry.
Airbus is a consortium comprising Germany's Daimler-Benz Aerospace, British Aerospace, Aerospatiale of France and Spain's CASA.
"Potentially this is going to be the biggest industrial company in Europe," said Sir Richard Evans, chief executive of British Aerospace.
The Airbus consortium said it was pressing ahead with plans to build the world's biggest passenger jet despite warnings from Boeing that the "superjumbo" market was not big enough for both of them.
Boeing, weighing a $5 billion plan to build a stretch version of its 747 jumbo, said Airbus would be committing financial suicide with its $8 billion project, the 550-seat A3XX.
